docs.lead_paragraph: Sullivan gets it right when he chides those who complain about the high cost of prescription drugs. A sense of entitlement about the ''right'' to affordable health care certainly contaminates the debate about the cost of drugs in particular and health care more generally. As Sullivan correctly argues, the pharmaceutical industry is part of the capitalist system, and it takes huge financial risks to develop its products. Part of the payoff for taking these risks is a higher profit margin. However, the subscription rates of health insurance are going through the roof to pay for bills like Sullivan's, and his employer is most likely footing the bill for the increase. The question becomes, How long will his employer, who is really the ''merciful'' figure in this scenario, be willing to play the role of rescuer? If current trends continue, more and more companies will, out of financial necessity, decline to supply reasonable health coverage for their employees. Mark Brody, M.D. Providence, R.I.
docs.abstract: Dr Mark Brody letter on Andrew Sullivan's article (Oct 29) on pharmaceutical industry; holds Sullivan correctly argues that pharmaceutical industry is part of capitalist system, and it takes huge financial risks to develop its products
docs.snippet: Sullivan gets it right when he chides those who complain about the high cost of prescription drugs. A sense of entitlement about the ''right'' to affordable health care certainly contaminates the debate about the cost of drugs in particular and...

docs.lead_paragraph: The president of the University of Pennsylvania, Judith Rodin, the first woman to run an Ivy League institution, had the highest annual salary and benefits of any college president in the country in 1998-99, receiving $655,557, a survey by The Chronicle of Higher Education shows. Dr. Rodin tops a list of presidents with steadily climbing compensation packages. Six collected more than $500,000 in 1998-99, compared with only one in 1995-96, and 74 -- nearly double the number three years ago -- earned at least $300,000. In addition, Harry C. Payne, the retiring president of Williams College, received $878,222, most of it in long-term retirement benefits.

headline.main: First Woman to Lead Ivy League College Is the Highest-Paid University President

docs.abstract: Chronicle of Higher Education reports that Judith Rodin, president of University of Pennsylvania, had the highest annual salary and benefits of any college president in US in 1998-99, receiving $655,557; six college presidents collected more than $500,000, and 74 earned at least $300,000; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Readers gave the usual suspects (particularly O.J.) a thorough going over, as they did Frank Rich for recycling them in his article on ''The Age of the Mediathon.'' And Andrew Sullivan's defense of drug companies, played against his own generous insurance plan, also drew heavy, often envious, mail.

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN all else fails, when you sense the audience starting to drift toward the exits, go with whatever worked for you before. Stand-up comics know this. So do cabaret singers. Also newspaper columnists, while we're at it. And mayors, too.

headline.main: Bereft of Hits, Reprising Golden Oldies

docs.lead_paragraph: William S. Woodside, a prominent business and civic leader who used his positions as a platform to promote social change in the New York area and nationwide, died on Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 78 and also had homes in Scottsdale, Ariz., and Litchfield, Conn. The cause was lung disease, said his wife, Migs.

docs.lead_paragraph: Everyone at City Hall could tell this week that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani was feeling like his old self again. He zestfully scolded a reporter at a news conference for his ''pathetic, sophomoric silliness,'' told an angry math teacher during a town hall meeting that the man was acting ''like a child,'' then reprimanded another teacher for her ''outrageous'' assertion that she deserved more money than a garbage collector because of her master's degree.

headline.main: The Milder Mayor Regains His Roar; Giuliani Returns to His Critical Self

docs.abstract: Six months after New York City Mayor Rudolph W Giuliani withdrew from Senate race, following cancer diagnosis and revelations about his marriage, much in administration is back to normal; he scolded reporters during press conference and sparred verbally with teachers during town hall meeting; speculation about political life following second term as mayor discussed; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-8 In Vietnam, Clinton Honors Soldiers From Both Sides Tens of thousands of Vietnamese, many of them former soldiers who once battled the United States, poured into the streets of Hanoi to welcome President Clinton. In a televised speech, he honored soldiers on both sides of ''the conflict we call the Vietnam War and you call the American war,'' but though he equated their sacrifices, he never delved into the causes they represented. A1 Senator-elect Hillary Rodham Clinton visited a village outside Hanoi to meet with women helped by a foreign lending program. A8

docs.lead_paragraph: At first blush, it looked like a typical fender bender: a 1989 Mercury sedan with four people inside ran into the car of a woman driving alone in downtown Brooklyn. But even though a police officer noted in his accident report that there were no injuries, three passengers in the Mercury were taken to a medical clinic, where they were treated for back and neck pains. While the fender bender attracted little attention at the time, federal investigators now say the accident was not accidental at all, but rather the work of a sophisticated insurance fraud ring whose members staged nearly 30 similar car crashes in the last four years, using false medical claims to cheat insurance companies out of more than $1 million.

headline.main: Car Crashes Were Staged For Fraud, U.S. Charges

docs.abstract: Insurance fraud ring is broken up and 53 members are charged in Federal District Court in Brooklyn with mail fraud and insurance fraud; led by Ruslan Erlikh and Alexander Lakhter, workers at Medical Arts Rehabilitation Clinic in Brooklyn, ring staged automobile accidents, then, with phony injuries, accident victims were treated at clinic; reimbursements from insurance companies ran from $10,000 to $20,000 for every passenger supposedly treated; scheme was uncovered when doctors who were formerly associates at clinic contacted investigators and said they believed their names were being forged on fake insurance claims; insurance companies investigated independently; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Sibirsky Alyuminiy, a major Russian aluminum producer, took steps to gain control of the country's second-largest automaker, Gorkovsky Avtomobilny Zavod, known as GAZ, to keep the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development from getting GAZ stock. Sibirsky said it now owned more than 25 percent of GAZ, enough to halt a proposal to give the development bank equity in exchange for the carmaker's debt. It bought the shares in the open market, it said. The bank has been trying to recoup a $65 million loan since GAZ, which builds Volga cars, stopped making payments last year. It has said it wants to resolve the issue with the company's management, which it helped to establish a joint venture with Fiat of Italy. A spokesman for the bank said it would not comment.

headline.main: Move Made to Control Russian Automaker

docs.abstract: Leapfrog Group, comprised of 60 of country's largest companies, announces plans to push hospitals to reduce medical errors that are to blame for deaths of tens of thousands of patients each year; members of Leapfrog Group say they will encourage their employees to use hospitals that act to improve patient safety; companies also plan to favor hospitals where drugs and medicals services are ordered on computerized systems that reject dangerous mistakes; companies in Leapfrog Group insure total of 20 million people (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: As a busy internist, Dr. Bruce Moskowitz frequently prescribes cholesterol-lowering medicines and osteoporosis drugs for his elderly patients. Like most physicians, he is no stranger to pharmaceutical sales representatives, and he often chats with them about his preference in medication. But the drug companies know more about Dr. Moskowitz than he realizes. Over the past decade, with the advent of sophisticated computer technology, pharmaceutical manufacturers have been quietly compiling resumes on the prescribing patterns of the nation's health care professionals, many of whom have no idea that their decisions are open to commercial scrutiny.

headline.main: High-Tech Stealth Being Used To Sway Doctor Prescriptions

docs.abstract: Article in series, Medicine Merchants, examining business of pharmaceuticals, describes vigorous and apparently successful effort by drug makers to sway doctors' prescribing habits; centerpiece of effort is so-called 'prescriber profiles,' resumes on prescribing patterns of nation's health care professionals, compiled with advent of sophisticated computer technology; profiles raise questions both about privacy of doctors' prescribing decisions, and how much commercial pressures influence them; drug companies spent $13.9 billion promoting their products last year, and 87 percent of that was aimed at doctors and small group of nurse practitioners and physicians' assistants who can prescribe medications; pharmaceutical sales representatives offer doctors trinkets, staff lunches and dinners, and free weekends at resorts; most doctors do not believe such entreaties affect their professional behavior, but some studies suggest otherwise; overall spending on pharamaceutical promotion increased more than 10 percent last year; experts estimate that companies collectively spend $8,000 to $13,000 a year per physician; photos; graph (L)
